Award.AwardTitle: Ecological dynamics of vertically transmitted symbionts in hosts with complex life histories
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many plants and animals harbor microbial symbionts, i.e., microbes that live on or in individuals of a host species, which are transmitted from host parent to offspring. However, there is striking variation in the frequency of microbial symbiosis across host species and even among populations of the same species. In some cases, a microbial symbiont species is present in all individuals of a host species, leading to tight integration of the ecology and evolution of host and symbiont. In other cases, such as fungal symbionts living within plants, the symbiont occurs at intermediate frequencies, with symbiotic and symbiont-free individuals co-occurring within host populations. This project will address the question of why there is wide variation in the frequency of host-symbiont associations. Given the strong evolutionary and ecological impacts of microbial symbionts, answering this question is a major challenge in biology. This project will test the hypothesis that the life history traits of the host species can explain much of the observed variation in symbiosis. Theory suggests that the population dynamics of symbionts are determined by how they affect the fitness of their host and the efficiency of their transmission among individual hosts. Host species with more complex life histories (longer lifespan, repeated reproduction, different stages of development) have more opportunities to be affected by symbionts and to lose them. This project will develop new mathematical models to examine the influence of host life history traits on symbiont population dynamics, and use field experiments to test model predictions. Experimental work will focus on the well-studied model system of grasses and their fungal symbionts. Symbiont dynamics in annual host grasses will be compared to dynamics in perennial host grasses that have more complex life histories. The integration of theoretical and field-based research is expected to provide a transformative approach to understanding and predicting the dynamics of symbionts.

A theoretical understanding of the dynamics of symbionts that are passed from parents to their offspring has broad application in conservation biology, ecosystem management and epidemiology. For example, global climate change has disrupted key symbioses, with warmer waters causing coral bleaching and drier climates altering the frequency and outcomes of animal and plant symbioses. This research will generate a framework for evaluating the responses of host-symbiont interactions to ongoing global change. In addition, this project will train students in using mathematical approaches to addressing fundamental questions in microbial ecology and evolution. Finally, the research team will develop hands-on projects for high school classrooms to illustrate concepts in the ecology and evolution of symbiosis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most plants and animals (including humans) are hosts to a diverse assemblage of micro-organisms that live on and inside us as ‘symbionts’. Many of these symbiotic microbes are heritable, meaning they are transmitted from parents to their offspring. Heritable microbial symbionts play an important role in host health, and many are being harnessed for their potential to improve human lives via agricultural and disease control initiatives. Given their ecological importance and their value to society, there is a need to better understand the factors that govern the distribution and abundance of heritable microbial symbionts.

One intriguing pattern observed in many plant and animal populations is that heritable microbes are highly variable in their population-level prevalence. Many populations consist of mixtures of symbiotic and non-symbiotic hosts. This is surprising because, if these symbionts are beneficial to their host, they are expected to sweep through the entire population. Observations of variable and often intermediate symbiont prevalence open up new questions that this study was designed to address: What factors control the prevalence of heritable symbionts in host populations? Are mixtures of symbiotic and non-symbiotic hosts ever stable, or might these be a transient state on a path to symbiont fixation or elimination? The investigators addressed these questions using a combination of mathematical models and field experiments with grasses and their vertically transmitted fungal microbes in east Texas.

The results of this study indicate that two processes control the prevalence of symbionts in their host populations: (1) the influence of the symbiont of its host’s fitness and (2) the rate at which symbiotic microbes are retained within and across host generations. Usually, a stronger benefit to hosts leads to greater symbiont prevalence in the host population; surprisingly, however, the mathematical models identified some conditions under which the opposite occurs. Field experiments with grass-endophyte symbioses showed that mixtures of symbiotic and non-symbiotic hosts may be stable: the investigators found that endophyte prevalence increased with endophytes were initially rare and decreased when they were initially common, yielding a stable intermediate. However, these outcomes were sensitive to environmental factors like temperature and precipitation. This suggests that the changes in climate expected under ongoing global change may have unexpected consequences for the microbial partners of many plants and animals, and thus for the viability of host populations.

This research has advanced knowledge of the forces that shape patterns of microbial distribution and abundance. This new understanding may help scientists leverage the power of symbiotic partners in medicine, agriculture, and public health. Beyond the scientific advances, this project also provided training opportunities for dozens of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, including students from groups that are sorely under-represented in STEM fields.
